title: How to Make an Aces Poker Cake

steps.headline: Bake cake in one 9x13" pan following recipe or box instructions.
steps.description: Chocolate cake is popular and provides good contrast to the white frosting.

steps.headline: Allow cake to cool to room temperature.
Cut cake in half and trim edges to make two 9x6" cakes with sharp corners.
Using a cake leveler, level both cakes to the same height.
steps.description: Levelers are available at cooking and craft stores. If you don't have a leveler, you can use a serrated bread knife to cut the tops off the cakes, although this requires patience and skill.

steps.headline: Remove an additional 1/4" off the top of the second cake using the leveler.
steps.description: This difference in height will provide the illusion of one card on top of the other. Picture of a leveler:

steps.headline: Cut a large notch out of the shorter cake (the second cake).
steps.description: The second cake will resemble an "L" after the notch is removed.

steps.headline: Place both cakes on decorative board and insert the taller cake in the notch of the second cake as shown above.
Frost using buttercream frosting.
steps.description: Take care to preserve the sharp relief of the cards. Press the fondant into the 1/4" ridge where the "top" card overlays the "bottom" card.

steps.headline: Prepare very large piece of white fondant and apply to cake.
steps.description: See tip in "How to Make Fondant."

steps.headline: Use this image as a guide:
Using a red food coloring pen, draw the letter "A" on the cards.
Prepare small amount of red fondant and cut out 1 large diamond, two small diamonds, 1 large heart, and 1 small heart.
steps.description: See tips for making red fondant and cutting it.

steps.headline: Apply diamonds to "top" card, using small amount (one drop) of water (or icing gel).
Test fit the heart on the center of the "bottom" card.
steps.description: Note where the top card hides the heart, and cut the heart to provide the illusion of being covered by the top "card."

steps.headline: Apply hearts to "bottom" card using small amount of water (or icing gel).
Smooth fondant using smoother.See tip in "How to Make Fondant."
Frost the cake shavings and the notch with left-over frosting for the kids.

text: Bake cake in one 9x13" pan following recipe or box instructions. Chocolate cake is popular and provides good contrast to the white frosting. Allow cake to cool to room temperature.  Cut cake in half and trim edges to make two 9x6" cakes with sharp corners.  Using a cake leveler, level both cakes to the same height. Levelers are available at cooking and craft stores. If you don't have a leveler, you can use a serrated bread knife to cut the tops off the cakes, although this requires patience and skill. Remove an additional 1/4" off the top of the second cake using the leveler. This difference in height will provide the illusion of one card on top of the other. Picture of a leveler: Cut a large notch out of the shorter cake (the second cake). The second cake will resemble an "L" after the notch is removed. Place both cakes on decorative board and insert the taller cake in the notch of the second cake as shown above.  Frost using buttercream frosting. Take care to preserve the sharp relief of the cards. Press the fondant into the 1/4" ridge where the "top" card overlays the "bottom" card. Prepare very large piece of white fondant and apply to cake. See tip in "How to Make Fondant." Use this image as a guide:  Using a red food coloring pen, draw the letter "A" on the cards.  Prepare small amount of red fondant and cut out 1 large diamond, two small diamonds, 1 large heart, and 1 small heart. See tips for making red fondant and cutting it. Apply diamonds to "top" card, using small amount (one drop) of water (or icing gel).  Test fit the heart on the center of the "bottom" card. Note where the top card hides the heart, and cut the heart to provide the illusion of being covered by the top "card." Apply hearts to "bottom" card using small amount of water (or icing gel).  Smooth fondant using smoother.See tip in "How to Make Fondant."  Frost the cake shavings and the notch with left-over frosting for the kids.
